summary: Director Woody Allen's love letter to New York City stars Allen as frustrated television writer Isaac Davis, a twice-divorced malcontent facing middle age alone after his wife, Jill (Meryl Streep), leaves him for a woman. Isaac is dating fresh-faced Tracy (Mariel Hemingway), a high school girl he knows is wrong for him, and begins to wonder if he and brainy writer Mary (Diane Keaton), the mistress of his best friend, Yale (Michael Murphy), might make a better couple.

reviews.content:
My 2022 commitment to see every movie featuring Meryl Streep continues.

In 1979 she appeared in Manhattan, playing the ex-wife of Woody Allen's character.

The Gershwin soundtrack was sublime and the black-and-white cinematography of 1970's Manhattan was a buffet for the eyes.

Now I need to go take a shower to get the stench of 96 minutes of Woody Allen repeatedly talking about his sexual prowess as he dates an underage girl (Mariel Hemingway) and hangs out with his unpleasant friends off of me.
Uninteresting confused movie that was a chore to get through.

My favorite Allen to date. I still find it hard to encompass the whole movie in one review with just two viewings, but everything I've grasped works for me. Brilliant cinematography thanks to an essential black & white; legendary soundtrack from the very first scene; typical Allen's wit at its finest distilled into a relentless screenplay; morally compelling and romantically universal. This masterpiece speaks to me, and it's hella fascinating to hear what it has to say. I'd watch it all again just to see Tracy paralyzed by her emotions around the end of the movie. We are but hostages of passions.

Allen's Manhattan is a director's lovingly idealized depiction of New York City, with glossy black and white cinematography making the landscape seem polished and ethereal. Towering buildings loom and landmarks stand like vaunted monuments; while the grime can't really be avoided in any depiction of New York ca. 1980, it's downplayed and treated like an oddly cherished part of the city's identity. At one point, we trail along behind a white Mustang as it cruises (alone) near the Hudson, listening in on the conversation between the passengers 30 feet ahead. There's no ambient noise, no traffic, no echoes from ten million other lives. It may not be realistic, but it does certainly look great. 

In this somewhat fictionalized playground of the intelligentsia steps Woody Allen as Isaac Davis, the next name given to the same personality that Allen does in most of classics - fretful, highly educated, verbose, and with a sardonic wit. But that's because his character works so well, and is pretty much endlessly entertaining. Isaac forms the centerpiece of a network of current and former lovers, friends, and colleagues who explore the possibilities of companionship through a series of small-scale encounters and everyday meetings where their sincere discussions are intermixed with heavy doses of humor and sarcasm. The roles are all well-played enough for the film to function as a straight-up comedy, but as the runtime rolls on you begin to see that there is an emotional depth behind it all - nobody is sure of themselves, everyone is making it up as they go along, and the passions are fickle. In this carefully photographed NYC that is beautifully accentuated by the musical talents of George Gershwin, there is a commentary on love and life that will end up hitting surprisingly hard after getting you to let your guard down with some great comedy.

Then you get thrown off by the middle-aged Allen having an openly sexual relationship with a 17-year-old girl, and you've got to spend the rest of your day muttering about how "it was a different time," so you can keep liking the film. (4/5)
only one of the greatest, most iconic movies ever made. Gamechanger of gamechangers. Woody Allen is a genius!
A smart, funny, poignant and romantic movie that feels bad due to recent Woody Allen acusations.

Easily one of the very best films of the 1970s. Woody Allen confidently keeps the comedy and drama in perfect balance while coaxing luminous turns from Diane Keaton, Meryl Streep & Mariel Hemingway. George Gershwin's legendary music combined with Gordon Willis' genius black and white cinematography perfectly captures New York's energy and essence; it will never again be this romantic.

Impressive movie. Was sceptical about it first but was won over by its mesmerizing cinematography, its charm, interesting intellectual in a not-boring way dialogues and its ultimate optimism. Every character is distinct and so it gives more interest in watching them interact with each other. The character of Hemingway eventually wins the prize as the most humane.

This is another fun romantic comedy by Woody Allen. I have started a long journey of watching all his movies and after 5 of them, I have to say that all were just so delightful to watch. Manhattan was no different: it is fun, it has a good story, great dialogues and beautiful scenes of his beloved Manhattan. Isaac Davis is the main character here (played by Woody, who mastered in playing this similar character over and over), a 40 years old comedy writer that divorced twice and now continues to look for the one relationship¬†of his life.¬†He is currently dating a 17 year old girl who seems to adore him and with whom he seems to feel very safe and just himsef. In this relationship he is the experimented one who is in control of things, he seems to consider this as a temporary thing until he is able to find someone with a proper age. This already hints the feeling that shows up constantly in the movie: people expect to know what they want and feel, who they love more and selfishly chose the best option. Of course, reality is much more complicated than that. Yale, Isaac's close friend, has a marriage of more than a decade but is having his third affair with a woman named Mary. They clearly have strong feelings for each other but also feel a (hypocrite?) guilt for the secret relationship. Isaac meets Mary and, while he is completely annoyed in their first interaction by her intelectual arrogance, it already seems that they will be together at some point. As Yale struggles to find time to be with his mistress, Isaac starts to fill that role and gets involved with Mary as their first encounter suggested. After that, the movie goes on to show us more of the feeling pointed out before as people seem to be so concerned about finding their true love (maybe just true for some time) that hurting the others envolved becomes just an inevitable consequence. The turn of events then is as much unpredictable (at least to me) as the connection between Mary and Isaac was on the first encounter, showing how good directors might even use apparently predictable moments at their favor. Woody's direction in fact is one I am starting to appreciate a lot; I loved the initial scenes of Manhattan while he starts his book (already so indecisive about love and how to describe it), the shots that resembles old silent films are also very interesting and the length of most scenes just blew my mind (it must be a true test for good actors). The movie has a nice and simple story which is told at an amazing rythm that just feels like it is how it was supposed to be (no boring sections at all), there are several funny moments as usual, dialogues are simple but sharpe and entertaining and the beautiful wide shots of Manhattan just complete the whole thing. It might not be the most amazing film but what is not to love?
Really uncomfortable, Mariel Hemingway is the only high point.

Manhattan Pros: Fantastic Acting Amazing Directing Outstanding Writing Striking Cinematography Magnificent Editing Excellent Musical Score Brilliant Pacing Superb Storytelling Mixes comedy and drama well Sublime chemistry between each actor Cons: The storyline has a couple of predictable moments here and there Overall Grade: A (9.5/10)

You know those beautiful 17 year old women attracted to 42 year old balding, midget men who are failed tv writers? No, me neither.

Creepy film. Only good thing about it is that it's twice as watchable as The equally rambling but even more boring Annie Hall.

Manhattan is a very good movie with excellent writing, a lot of depth and New York City in it's best movie role. George Gershwin doesn't hurt either.
But I see a movie that, when I first viewed it in college, made me pretty uneasy. Woody Allen with a beautiful girl was hard to understand. It didn't make sense. And then, there it is on the big screen in black and white. He gets girls that are pretty and younger -- so young that it's illegal -- so that he has power over them.
It's disgusting when you see he actually practiced this in his real life. Looking back, it takes a lot away from this movie.
I don't care if I'm the only one in the world that thinks it, but Woody Allen is one of the most overrated filmmakers I've ever seen.

Black and white just doesn't cut it.  The world is in color, why isn't the movie?  No young person wants to watch a movie such as this, and it is particularly galling because color was the standard film choice when the movie was made.  I do not agree with people who say that limiting the shots to black and white somehow "improve" the movie.  It may make it easier for the cinematographer and for Allen's storytelling, but it does nothing to illuminate or move along the story.  As a postcard this may work, but as a movie, something fluid and meant to be living, it is limiting and short-sighted.  A very poor choice that cannot be supported rationally.  It meaningfully detracts from the movie.

A love letter to the city in the first few minutes, then the movie itself, Manhattan had many of the subtle one-liners we associate with Woody ("You're so beautiful I can barely keep my eyes on the [taxi] meter." was probably my favorite) but was just missing something more for me to push it into the 80s. Isaac (Woody Allen), forty-two and dating a seventeen-year-old definitely didn't age well, even if she (Mariel Hemingway) is the most mature character in the movie. And that might be the biggest issue I had with Manhattan, is that the main cast of characters are largely unlikable in a generally likeable movie. I suppose it's a microcosm of a piece of NYC that still exists today; successful, egotistical, neurotic people making problems for themselves, spending too much on rent, and looking at art. I also could've moved it into the 80s with a better ending. It was so shitty how Isaac treated Tracy, only for the film to want us to want them together in the end. It did give us that gorgeous shot of the Queensboro Bridge, however, even if the bench was never really there.
Literally shaking dude

Allen's greatest love letter to New York City. Allen, Keaton & Streep give solid performances and Hemingway was nominated for a Best Supporting Actress Oscar as Allen's young girlfriend. Magnificent cinematography done with wide-angle cinemascope and presented in black-and-white. The script is wit of the highest order. The selection of music is outstanding. Oscar-nominated story by Allen & Marshall Brickman examine impossible relationships and guilt complexes with witty humor and touching emotion. Irony, good acting and soundtrack always make a movie worth watching. And Manhattan can boast the best here . 8/10

Manhattan is a boring and worthless movie, that won't appeal even romance genre fans. What it does in a great way is show and explore New York places combined with a good soundtrack, but the rest is not appealing.
see myself , see everyone

One of the definitive love letters to New York City this is a film that provided an aspirational vision of adulthood to me at a young age as troubling as that thought was when revisiting the film. Watching the film now I see that it was as brilliant as I thought it was when I first saw it but in different ways as I was now able to look past the glamour of a group of highly intelligent people having conversations about art in a beautiful location to see how lonely all of these people were despite their talents and position in life. I no longer aspire to be divorced and can see that suffering is painful even if you look attractive or have seen several art films. With this ability to look past the surface attractions of the film I could see how it delved into the emotional confusion that people experience when they reach a certain point in their lives and begin to feel lonely.

Television writer Isaac Davis, Woody Allen, has left his job ostensibly to write a boom but struggles to formulate ideas. He wallows in the pains he experienced during his relationship with his ex-wife Jill, Meryl Streep, who left him for her lesbian lover and is now writing a tell all book about their marriage. In trying to find himself he has fallen into a relationship with the sexually explorative teenager Tracy, Mariel Hemingway, who he attempts to break up with repeatedly. He eventually leaves her when he falls in love with a woman his own age in the damaged Mary Wilkie, Diane Keaton, who happens to be the former mistress of his married best friend Yale Pollack, Michael Murphy. Davis and Wilkie break up when she returns to Pollack and Davis finds himself alone despite trying to reconcile with Tracy.

For some this could be considered a better film than Annie Hall (1977), although I still like that film more, as it presents the audience with a tougher ending in that this man never really loved any of the women he was romantically involved with. His relationship with Jill was based on his physical desire for her as he often describes her as attractive while failing to take into account her combative personality or lack of attraction to him. Tracy is a girl that he uses to try to recapture his youth as he remains immature even though he knows about classic films and enjoys wielding a certain power over his inexperienced girlfriend while also having an ‚Äòequal' in terms of maturity in many ways. Finally he falls into a romance with the equally tragic Wilkie who has her heart set on various men who she can not commit to because they either overwhelm her or do not provide her with enough of their time. She is shown to throw herself wholeheartedly into a relationship at it's beginning before backing away for fear of being hurt as all of the rejection she has experienced in previous relationships is recalled. He is not satisfied in his relationships with any of these women and is in a perpetual state of discontent as he wants what the other women can provide when he is with one of his love interests.

Why is it then that this sad little story of a weak man who does not understand his desires or needs makes New York City look so glorious? Mixed in amongst the depressing story and troubled characters are scenes in which characters visit the landmarks of the city which are seen in glorious black and white and set to a score full of classic songs. The opening and closing montages featuring shots of New York City feel exactly like what one imagines when they think of a stereotypical Woody Allen film and for good reason because few directors have the knowledge of the city that he does. There is one spectacular scene in which Allen and Keaton wander through a museum exhibit set in the solar system and without seeing their faces we understand exactly how each of them feels as they consider starting a relationship before he hesitates. Where the films of other New York directors focus on gangsters or plain middle class families Allen aims for insecure upper class Manhattanites who concern themselves with The Grand Illusion (1937) and Kierkegaard. It is too easy to be taken in by these people as they seem to know everything about culture and speak with authority but underneath all of this Allen tells us that even those living in the greatest city on earth can feel hurt, rejection and even love.
On par with his previous masterpiece Annie Hall Woody Allen's study of love life amidst New York intellectuals scores  with beautiful b&w cinematography and more subtle humor than before.
A great beginning, a mediocre middle, and a terrific ending.
Woody Allen at his best, interesting script and beautiful photography.

A perfect film. All of Woody‚Äôs genius, warmth, intellect, cynicism and humor in one of the best films of the 70‚Äôs. I‚Äôve converted those who profess to ‚Äòhate Woody Allen movies‚Äô with this one.
Total MEH with a bit of YUCK. Woody Allen's real-life perversions are expressed within this dated crapper.
I gather this boring stuff is mostly loved by new-yorkers...

Manhattan tells a tale that is funny and romantic, even agonizing at times, but it never looses its optimistic core. Woody creates a web of relationships that are all so tangible and therefore make it hard for you not to relate to any of them.

Actually I'm disappointed because the movie didn't answer a lot of question, such as:

* How on earth the tone slips so gracefully between the gut-busting one-liners and emotionally exhausting romantic moments like that?

* How can a black-and-white film still be considered as one of the most beautiful movies ever with its gorgeous cinematography?

* How can a 96 min film has such character development? * How can a single quote make a lot of change to the characters and the story itself?

* How can a soundtrack that features only the rhythms of songs can speak for the hero at every stage he get through?  * How can a movie this complex and presents messages about love and loss seems to be so simple that can be rewatched. .... and many more questions left unanswered.


Mariel Hemingway performance is phenomenal! Hands down one of the smartest and most subtle screenplays ever written!

By far, Manhattan is the best Woody Allen movie. By the way, I'm a big fan of Annie Hall.

This movie is the definition of "Bittersweet"! 

(10/10)

I‚Äôd like to go on record in saying that I am pretty good at keeping my opinions about actors‚Äô personal lives completely separate from my opinions of the films they make (and frankly I don‚Äôt know enough about whatever scandals Woody Allen has been involved in to form a strong opinion anyways.) But what his character does in a film I‚Äôm perfectly willing to judge. I struggled early with Manhattan because statutory rape just isn‚Äôt something I‚Äôm capable of chuckling about. This movie asks me to see it as no big deal and a genuine relationship I‚Äôm supposed to enjoy. Not only was the main character actively involved in this inappropriate relationship, everyone around him reacts to it with casual acceptance. When I tried to compartmentalize this one aspect of the film, I still didn‚Äôt find myself laughing much. The humor is mostly built around Woody Allen‚Äôs neurotic personality, and his struggle in romantic relationships. I liked the cast, and the actors do have good comedic timing, but few of the jokes resonated with me enough to get me laughing . I was annoyed by the fact that the characters were pretty despicable, and everyone made the worst decisions. As a result, I didn‚Äôt like anybody in Manhattan at all. Plus Woody Allen made the pretentious decision to film it all in black-and-white for no discernible reason. Manhattan is basically all the things I dislike about other Woody Allen movies all rolled into one. I‚Äôve seen worse comedies, but Manhattan did little to interest me.
Movie about a weird 40 something guy who dates a 17 year old girl. Didn't like it.

Stumbled on this movie by chance when surfing VUDU's free movie with ads category. This is a great movie, Woody Allen's fantastic take on romance in the Big Apple. I loved the opening monologue, setting the tone of the movie. The soundtrack is great, the black and white photography worked perfect for this film. See this movie, you will not be disappointed.

This film is like Woody Allen's mixed up version of Lolita, underage girl and man around forty in a fairly romantic  relationship but with an art-film vibe to it. Unlike Kubrick this film has more humor. Despite the controversy and raciness of this film, it is still a masterpiece.

He likes this one, she likes him, or is it the other him, oh but he likes someone else again - who cares!  Empty little soap opera with an upper-middleclass NY bent.  Pretends like it wants to see beyond its own nose, but doesn't really mean it.

An oddly satisfying commentary on the nature of love. Carried by Woody Allen's zany persona, along with phenomenal supporting actors, witty satirization, historical plot tangents, and verbose yet never dull dialogue. Not to mention a moving encapsulation of New York City's soul.
No. Creepy, negative, rambly, pretentious, unfunny, gross worst of human drama, not an ounce of real romance. Competent film-making though.
Good story,everybody plays very well in that movie,except Woody Allen absolutely disaster

I love Manhattan even more than I do Annie Hall. I think this has incredible themes off love, regret and maturity. The movie also looks beautiful, the cinematography of New York in black and white was truly stunning. The performances were terrific from the whole cast. Woody Allen is his usual negative self but more lovable and his comic timing is spot on here. As is Diane Keaton's, you can't take your eyes off here in this movie. Mariel Hemingway shows real maturity in her performance, similarly to her character. Michael Murphy and Meryl Streep also do some good work here in the scenes that they are in. This doesn't take the regular route of a romance film luckily, it is actually very unpredictable and has no set path, like love itself.
Aptly employing George Gershwin's music and filming in black-and-white, Woody Allen composes a love serenade to the titular borough and its neurotic romanticists in one of his adored productions.

Grade - B+
'Manhattan' is a highly enjoyable addition to Woody Allen's filmography, with great performances and a witty script, all helped along by an excellent score by George Gershwin.

I don't think that there's any other movie that captures the essence and the beauty of what New York really is. Sure Taxi Driver does a marvelous job at showing New York but it's more so the underbelly of New York. Here, your getting to see how marvelous New York really is, and it's not even in color. Woody really nailed it to the tee. 

What a fantastic movie! Everything. The acting, the charm of the characters, the location, the writing. Everything.

Definitely deserves a re-watch.

If you ever wish to study cinema in any area, watch "Manhattan", it's a true movie lesson. First, its visual, the cinematography is so stunning that if this was a silent movie, the film would remain equally beautiful. The lighting in this movie is the greatest work done since The Godfather(1972). The way that Woody Allen shoots widely in closed places makes you feel inside the room. The chemistry between the actors, the naturalness of the dialogue and narration make this film completely unique and amazing. This is one of the greatest movie ever made.
even though woody allen is a creeper i liked the movie.

Director/screenwriter Woody Allen strikes gold once again in this glamourized, self-satisfying depiction of several lives and their relationships with one another in contemporary (late 1970s) Manhattan. Cast includes Woody Allen at his most neurotic and hyperanalytical, Diane Keaton at her most abrasive and concealed, Meryl Streep at her most fed up and antipathetic, Mariel Hemingway at her brightest and most easygoing, and Michael Murphy at his most cocksure and seesawy. Fragile, dry humour deflates the grandest romantic gestures committed in this story, and, without ever coming close to preaching, confronts the viewer with a necessary deconstruction and reconstruction of romance, commitment, and separation.

Well, petty distractions turned watching this movie into an 8 hour extravaganza of rewinding and replaying, but it delivered despite how I watched it. Woody Allen makes me feel better about life. Always. I love his masterful delivery of moving art, I love his storytelling, I love his depth, I love that I can always relate to him and like him no matter what horrible things people are doing to each other in the movie, and I love that he gives that perspective to acknowledge that people are just people and are going to be fallible but can still be beautiful and loveable and worthy full fledged humans, flaws and all.  I loved the movie in its entirety, but as always with me it comes down to the ending being what makes or breaks a movie, and this ending was beautiful. When I'm at my lowest, multiple Woody Allen movies have reminded me that life is still worthwhile, and I'm glad this was one of those. I needed it. It's weird when someone speaks to your soul and you know you'll never get the opportunity to thank them.
Essentially Annie Hall 2 but more complex and shot in glorious black and white.

A brilliant romance between New York (Diane Keaton) and Allen, who masterfully portrays both one's natural love for, and natural longing to leave New York City. Allen's use of black and white filming and Rhapsody in Blue in the beginning underscores the idea of people over romanticizing the city, and also explains the unanimous love for New York City. However, just like in his relationship with Tracy (Mariel Hemingway) Allen wants to break away, and move on. A beautiful parallel. Allen also accurately portrays the personality of many New Yorkers.

"Well, I don't get angry, okay? I mean, I have a tendency to internalize. I can't express anger. That's one of the problems I have. I-I grow a tumor instead."
- Woody Allen

As somebody with a father who grew up in New York City, this line couldn't be more accurate. Truly the New Yorker way.

Allen makes few mistakes in this film -- it was very deftly done. Definitely one of my top films of all time.

I'm starting to doubt my ability to understand what ends cinema is actually supposed to achieve.  When films such as Manhattan and Citizen Kane are regarded as great achievements, I begin to feel as if some mechanism is not functioning in my brain, or perhaps is over-functioning in everybody else's. 

This is the story of a bunch of boring, unlikable, over educated but under-scientific privileged white people trying to create sexual relationships with each other.  Who cares?  Why do people enjoy these movies?  It didn't teach me anything, none of the character's behavior seemed admirable  or interesting.  

This movie reminds me of weak and asinine people, and doesn't do George Gershwin's music any justice.  (Although the brief dialogue about Gustav Mahler being overrated is the only thing that I resonated with in the film).  

I'm going back to studying physics and listen to Beethoven now.  Bye.
"-You know a lot of geniuses, y'know. You should meet some stupid people once in a while, y'know, you could learn something."
My go-to NY love letter. Really interesting narrative on relationships and how they intertwine uncontrollably.
Manhattan takes Woody Allen's love for New York plus women to a whole new level with being bittersweet and glorious in cinematography

One of Woody Allen's best films, Manhattan gives the viewer an inside look into the complexities of what love can truly represent to different people. Beautifully crafted, well-written, and well-acted, Manhattan is a triumph.

cinegeek.de Ich hatte ganz vergessen, wie wundervoll Woody Allens Manhattan ist und die Balance zwischen Kom√∂die und Romanze mit traumwandlerischer Sicherheit h√§lt! Einige Jahre lang hatte ich Manhattan nicht mehr gesehen und konnte mich nur noch an die witzigsten Einzeiler erinnern und daran, dass die Liebesgeschichte zwischen einem Mann √§lteren Datums und einem Schuldm√§dchen erz√§hlt wird. Manhattan ist aber so viel mehr! Es ist kein Film √ºber die Liebe, es ist ein Film √ºber den Verlust. Der Soundtrack beinhaltet eine Menge romantischer Songs, die im Grunde gar nicht zum Film passen, dessen Protagonist Isaac (Allen) die Liebe gar nicht kennt. Seine Sommerliebe heisst Tracy (Mariel Hemingway, die Nichte des Dichters) und vordergr√ºndig hat sie mit Isaac nichts gemein. Sie hat aber das, was ein Liebhaber so dringend braucht: Die F√§higkeit, ihren Gegen√ºber zu idealisieren. Genau darin besteht der Geburtsfehler dieser Beziehung, weil sich Isaac dessen gar nicht f√ºr w√ºrdig erachtet. Er f√ºhlt sich nicht als etwas Besonderes und sieht f√ºr sich und Tracy keine Zukunft. Angesprochen, auf ihr Vorhaben, in London zu studieren, weiss er nichts Besseres zu antworten, als dass sie ihn als sch√∂ne Erinnerung behalten soll. Die H√§lfte der Zeit, in der sie zusammen sind, versucht Isaac Schluss zu machen - letztg√ºltig mit Erfolg. Er sagt ihr, er w√ºrde eine andere lieben. Hemingway reagiert ganz simpel und herzzerreissend, w√§hrend Isaac wie immer zu viel redet. In dieser Szene wird mir bewusst, dass ich die Figur des Isaac nicht mag. Er hat etwas Grausames an sich. Sp√§ter erz√§hlt er seinem Freund; ''I think I really missed a good bet when I let Tracy go". Vielleicht hat er das, obwohl er bereits 42 ist und sie erst 17? Darum geht es aber nicht in Manhattan. Der Film handelt vom Zynismus und der Oberfl√§chlichkeit solcher Menschen wie Isaac, die permanent um sich selbst kreisen, w√§hrend sie kultiviertes Zeug quasseln. Die Tr√ºmmer seines Beziehungsleben umfassen ausserdem seine Ex-Frau (Meryl Streep), die nun den gemeinsamen Sohn mit einer anderen Frau gross zieht. So wie Isaac erkl√§rt Yale Mary, sie h√§tten keine Zukunft und √ºbergibt sie an seinen Kumpel: ''You'd be great for her." Zwischen Isaac und Mary entsteht eine Liebelei, bis Yale sie wieder zur√ºck fordert und behauptet, er sei zuerst da gewesen. Beide M√§nner sind √ºberfordert im Angesicht echter Gef√ºhle. Manhattan handelt deshalb auch nicht von der gegenw√§rtigen Liebe, sondern der zur√ºckliegenden. Es ist der Moment, wenn wir uns darauf besinnen, was wir gerade zerschlagen haben. Stellen wir uns Manhattan mal als konventionelle "Romantic Comedy" vor: Hier w√§ren Yale und Mary das zentrale Paar, Tracy und Isaac ihre besten Freunde. In seiner ganzen Karriere aber hat Woody Allen daran gearbeitet, die Charaktere aus der zweiten Reihe in den Mittelpunkt zu schieben. Isaacs Beziehung zu Mary hat nichts von einer "RomCom". Sie ist kompliziert, da Isaac nicht weiss, ob er nun vorw√§rts gehen soll oder nicht? Was f√ºr eine grandiose Idee ist es deshalb, diese Beziehung vor dem Hintergrund Manhattans zu filmen - denn New York liebt Woody Allen nun wirklich! Manhattan heisst der heimliche Hauptdarsteller des Films und in den Strassenschluchten verschwinden die permanent quatschenden Neuroiker. Die Untermalung mit Gershwins ''Rhapsody in Blue'' schafft es, dass wir uns transzendent f√ºhlen, einfach hochtragend! Dazu die ber√ºhmten Geb√§ude und Orte wie Guggenheim, Elaine's, Zabar's deli... Vermutlich bietet der Film so viele Insider, dass ich als Berliner gar nicht alles verstehen kann! Woody Allen weiss genau, wie einige Songs das Leben der meisten von uns untermalen. F√ºr Isaac hat er den passenden Song ausgesucht: ''But Not for Me''. Unvergesslich, das Finale, als Isaac endlich merkt, mit wem er zusammen sein will und los rennt: ''Strike Up the Band". All diese Schaupl√§tze in Verbindung mit den Songs h√§tten nicht die Wirkung ohne Gordon Willis' Schwarzweiss-Fotografie, die Manhattan zu einem der sch√∂nsten Filme aller Zeiten macht! Dank Willis wird die Stadt zum Hauptdarsteller. Er erweckt sie zum Leben! Diane Keaton, die bereits ein Star war, bevor sie Woody Allen heiratete, spielt Mary. Manhattan is a self-referential, self-deprecating if not an autobiographical work of Woody Allen. It is also brutally honest with abundant numbers of Freudian jokes and psychoanalysis.
This is Woody Allen at his finest.

Teeming with both genuine pathos and sheer hilarity, Manhattan is Woody Allen at the pinnacle of his considerable prowess and is only made more brilliant by its gorgeous cinematography and the beauty of the city is so dearly admires.

New York City is perhaps the only character large enough to overshadow Allen's trademark narcissism, and it appropriately stars in this film which encompasses byproducts of urban living, young adulthood, liberal self indulgence, and social exposition, fused together by an eye for city beauty, a reverence for history, and a timeless modern pulse.

From a stylish perspective, Manhattan presents a large step out for Woody Allen's tradition of filmmaking. It does not incorporate the same visual or story style to his trademark comic pieces as the film is more comedy-drama yet maintains the same form of atmosphere he establishes in a lot of his films. And in terms of visual style, the cinematography in the film is a lot more atmospheric as it takes on a wider range of angles and incurs more movement and editing than the standard piece. It establishes a feeling of isolation in the atmosphere for viewers and gives them a sense of peeking in on the underside of people's lives. This gives Manhattan a new level of complex depth to it and stronger meaning, and it allows the drama of the film to flourish. And the black and white style of the film gives it an interesting sense of nostalgia. It evokes memories to a much simpler time of cinema, and considering that Manhattan is a rather simple and easy film to watch. The black and white colour palette of the film and lighting evoke a truly classical feel, and that is a great thematic for a Woody Allen film because it makes it all the more meaningful coming from him, as if it is a stylish homage to the films he grew up with. The classical style of the musical score helps to add to this, so Manhattan really is an interesting experience.
Manhattan has the naturally lighthearted feel to it which makes it an easy viewing pleasure. It is not one of Woody Allen's funnier films, but the quality of the comedy in it is fine and it blends with the drama really well. Admittedly it is a rather familiar film in terms of subject matter, but it is still a touching sentiment which is crafter really well with a strong screenplay. The complicated exploration of relationships in Manhattan are an all new angle of exploration for Woody Allen. He has a natural knack for it, and in Manhattan he incorporates it with a new style of filmmaking. It is a very ambitious film, and while it is familiar and relatively slow in pace as well as so realistic in narrative that its drama can only hit a certain level of strength, it is an enjoyable experience. It is a gentle film with a lot of touching plot dynamics to it, although I feel that there is certain predictability to it. It is different to the predictability of a lot of his films as they tend to follow a formula. The thing about Manhattan is that the ending of the film is inevitable, and is somewhat of a letdown. Considering that it is another film about the relationship between characters played by Woody Allen and Diane Keaton, it has an ending to similar to Annie Hall from the preceding year. Both films are good, although Manhattan fails to reach the heights of Annie Hall. It is more stylish, but the fact that the ending is so similar makes it slightly disappointing. Considering the unpredictable nature of the film it would be hard to pick a perfect ending, but I guess I just felt that the one in Manhattan was a letdown which was a bit too similar to Annie Hall. But still, a lot of the other elements that Manhattan borrows from Annie Hall are good.
And thanks to a fine cast, Manhattan remains a solid film on a human level.
Woody Allen plays out a character less like his stereotypical nebbish than in many of his other films. This time he tones down to Jewish shtick and focuses more on a character who seems naturally like him. His performance is realistic and easily likable which makes the frequently cartoonish character a more humane one. This makes the sympathy in the film a lot stronger as the protagonist is one that audiences will more likely care about. Woody Allen's subtle comic approach to the material and legitimate dramatic work is just grand in Manhattan which makes it one of his greatest leading performances, and his chemistry with every other actor, particularly Diane Keaton, is just wonderful. I was thoroughly impressed with his leading performance in Manhattan as it is very far from indulgent.
Diane Keaton does a fine job in Manhattan as well. She conveys a great sense of confusion and unpredictability in the role which makes her an intriguing character. Her emotional confusion contributes a great part to the film's exploration of complicated love in relationships, and she pulls it off really easily. Her role is ripe with charisma and finely dramatic without ever descending to melodrama or any sort of cheap comic ploy. She steps away from her iconic Annie Hall role to deliver another excellent performance in a Woody Allen film, so her presence as the leading actress is very welcome.
Mariel Hemingway proves to make herself a likable foil in Manhattan as well. She has a youthful spirit to her and her chemistry with Woody Allen is just great. She is sweet, and in her young age she is easily able to work the best out of Woody Allen's script which is impressive as it is such complex stuff. She makes a name for herself very well in Manhattan, and despite a small period of screen time she is easily memorable.
Meryl Streep also delivers an early performance in Manhattan where viewers get to see her talents from the same year when she won the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress in Kramer vs. Kramer. Her brief appearance contributes some grand moments to the film, so she is really genial.

So Manhattan is a rather slow film with a somewhat unsatisfactory  ending and a sense of familiar themes, but it is powerfully stylish, touching and extremely well-acted which makes use of all of Woody Allen's greatest talents.

The first time I viewed "Manhattan" in high school, it repulsed me in a way that I couldn't put into words. After giving it a second look, I now see that I perceived it to be Allen's declaration of his own self-absolution, an embracing of his deeply flawed nature (the 17 year-old love interest specifically), when in actuality it proves to be less of Allen forgiving himself of his sins and more of his own self-flagellation. The perfect rendering of New York, the sentimental and nostalgic social-construct of an idea of New York, is intoxicating and emotionally mirrors his sense of self, the two irreparably fused and co-dependent at the same time. With a bittersweet tone, wealth of critical insight, and impeccable production, "Manhattan" is a masterpiece, and rivals only the great "Annie Hall" for the title of Allen's most perfect work.

Review:
This movie is definitely a tribute to New York City. The scenery looks great throughout the film and the black and white theme, really does work. As for the movie itself, it just seemed like your typical Woody Allen movie, which are usually about relationships between friends and lovers. For 1979, this must have been a unique movie because of its mixture between comedy and serious relationship issues, which we all can relate to, but for this day and age, we have seen this type of film many times before. The relationship between Woody and the young girl was interesting, along with the ex-wife, played by Meryl Streep, whose become a lesbian after having a child with Woody, so there's enough material to keep the movie watchable. Personally, it does go down as some of his best work because he got everything right, but I'm still struggling to get his humour. Watchable!

We can all see part of ourselves in Isaac/Allen. The film is nostalgic, wistful, yet with no intention of depicting a story from a single lens or to a single destination. What truly clicked within me are the few subtle moments filled with Isaac's mumbling and his looking away. Allen said "he has no problem in meeting women", yet with some careful thought, we realized he has no problem drawing women's attention, but failed at maintaining them. As in "Chapter 1", New York meant beautiful women and street smart guys who know all the angles. Isaac is witty, but not in the same way as the street smart guys. The women Isaac met are all beautiful, yet they're not particularly after Isaac's gifts. With an identity crisis, Isaac holds too strong of an ideal that's most likely developed from unsuccessful attempts with women and life. An intangible ideal is perfect for escaping reality and putting oneself at a higher ground above anything else. Yet Isaac is just an ordinary guy, with a witty sense of humor, chasing after delicately decorated faces, shaped by modern advertising, only with a romantic touch of his own interpretations. Allen Woody was absolutely incredible at interpreting the character that has struck my emotions so hard with the subtle, delicate moments.

A great film shot entirely in black and white, that many people believe is Woody Allen's best. Stylistically, I would agree even if I think some of the black and white is too dark, though I'm pretty sure that's intentional. There are 4 separate love stories here, so if this gets confusing, just read the next few sentences over and over again til you get it. Woody is in love with two women, Diane Keaton and 17 year old Mariel Hemingway. There's two. Then there is Michael Murphy and Diane Keaton, the former being married and Woody's best friend. That's three. The 4th and final is the real Woody Allen's love affair with New York. This is by far the most interesting of all the love stories in this flick. The way the film is shot and written and by using Gershwin tunes as the final brush stroke, Woody paints a picture of his New York. It is very easily, a New York anyone can see themselves living in. While it's not my favorite and I tend to the story is basically the same one he always tells, I've learned to enjoy this film more over the years. Tho I wouldn't mind a Gershwin only audio track on a future release. So I can sit back and pretend I am in the Woody Allen's ideal heaven. New York City.

How can you not fall in love with New York City after watching a movie like this!  How can you not fall in love with its people?  Or what about the music.  "Manhattan" is a classic. I might actually like this film more than I like Annie Hall.  The only real quibble I've got can be aimed at just about every Woody Allen film, and that is: why do all of these gorgeous women date a guy who looks like Woody Allen?  I mean, is he supposed to be playing himself in all of these films?  In the world of his movies, is he this big time celebrity just as he is in real life?  It's not that I have anything against beautiful women choosing the scrawny bookworm type, in fact, I welcome it.  It's just, I keep hearing time and again from people who make movies that you can't strain the suspension of disbelief by this wide a margin.  In fact, they've told me that there's no way anyone will buy a romance between a geeky looking guy and the hot supermodel.  Are my film professors just a bunch of jerks who've had their minds twisted by a Hollywood mode of thinking, or is it the sad truth?  Personally, I like to think that any good man fits well with any good woman regardless of what they look like, but, according to film school, most audiences just won't buy it.  On the subject of Woody Allen's Manhattan, I think it's a winner, and I found myself easily charmed by it regardless of the seeming mismatch between the romantic leads.

Woody Allen's love letter to New York City is as beautiful as its namesake. Focusing on day-to-day interactions, Manhattan plays more as a series of interesting conversations with relatable characters than as a narrative, very much in the vein of Ernest Hemingway's The Sun Also Rises. Like Hemingway, Allen has the most remarkable gift for writing dialog. With  Manhattan he crafts such organic conversations that one would think they were improvised rather than scripted. While the film embraces the corny side of romantics to mixed degrees of success, it also strikes at the heart of everyday life and resonates deeply on an emotional level. Allen crafted an unforgettable, nearly flawless film that will never be outdated.

Manhattan will always remain a classic.

By this point, people had already become acquainted with Allen's intelligence in portraying the love machinations of the New York intellectual crowd in a delightful and genuinely funny satirical way. With Manhattan he returned to that world with added grace and a more nostalgic style, including the usual perfect use of a jazz soundtrack and a wonderful black and white photography which indeed feels like a glorification of its titular setting. Already a modern classic at the time of its release, Manhattan is not only among the best film by Woody Allen but also one of the most poignant looks at the myth of romanticism and the mystery of adult and mature relationships.

But as there is a movie screen in between him and us we can enjoy his neurotic dialogue and strange tangents and ramblings and ravings and it doesn't matter that the other "pseudo-intellects" aren't all that likeable. It is absolute bliss just to watch them all stumbling through their lives talking absolute nonesense. A great cast, all with their little quirks and idiosyncracies. And you can't forget the absolutely beautiful shots of New York, the silhouettes, the streets, the cars, the people, and one of the most iconic and obvious moments; the long shot of Diane Keaton and Woody Allen sitting on a bench just before dawn looking at the lights on Queensboro Bridge. Can't say anything bad about this one. The man was at his peak.

The ultimate cinematic love letter to a given city. Woody Allen talks about the city life with an almost reluctant love at times. For all his neurotic tendencies, Allen loves this city, because he sees exactly as the audience does. Thanks to the lensing of Gordon Willis and the great writing and directing of Mr. Allen, we see New York like a grand cityscape filled with impossibly weird and complex people, and a painterly landscape that moves and breathes.

This is also a celebration of unrequited love, missed connections, and ambiguity. For all his musings on how pointless life ultimately is to him, Allen is a man who keeps coming back to "fate" or purpose, and that's all over this film.

Together they fit perfectly to be a black-and-white film about a black-and-white idea. Other than that, the performances are again brilliant and natural, and Allen succeeds in displaying truly beautiful romanticism in his, in my opinion, finest film.

Manhattan represents one of Woody Allen's greatest critical responses, widely considered to be among his best. It's a well conceived film, to be sure, with amazing cinematography, a unique story, and a script penned by Woody that is filled with his characteristic wit and dialogue, with good characterizations and an avoidance of clich√©s. 

Set against a beautiful backdrop of late 1970s New York, and filmed in black and white, it looks brilliant. The acting is as strong as most Allen pieces, with solid early performances from greats Diane Keaton and Meryl Streep. All of this contribute to what feels like a very real story. This is what Allen is perhaps best at, injecting humor and comedy into realistic situations.

My issue with Manhattan, however, is that the story isn't as involving or as engaging as his other works. It's also not nearly as funny. This is perhaps at least partly due to the dated nature of the film, not aging as well in humor as even some of his earlier works, such as the fantastic Annie Hall. It's enjoyable, but it never reaches the pinnacle of Allen's other work which are often more poignant, hilarious, and engaging.

Woody Allen's magnum opus. An ode to New York City in the guise of a complicated love story revolving around four people. Hemingway is heartbreaking as Allen's young, often naive lover. Keaton is the pseudo-intellectual that drives viewers and Allen batty with her arrogance. Shot is exquisite black and white, with the enduring image of Allen and Keaton sitting with the Queensboro Bridge in the background. Best scenes: the party scene wherein a female guest doing her best Judy Holiday impression quips: "I finally had an orgasm, and my doctor said it was the wrong kind," and Allen's character recording himself in the final fifteen minutes of the film.

In New York City, we find Woody Allen dating a woman (Mariel Hemingway, who was famed writer's Ernest daughter) that is more than two decades younger than him. He is a divorced man, whose ex-wife (Meryl Streep) has become a lesbian and writes a book that slams his ability to have sex. In addition, Woody is also friends with a married couple (Anne Byrne and Michael Murphy), in which the husband, who is a total visionary, begins engaging in a relationship with a writer (Diane Keaton). Oddly, the writer and Woody start to have an affair themselves, two-timing their other relationships. Interesting character study that is almost a Jerry Springer scene waiting to explode, but thankfully doesn't materialize to that extent (three different people are being screwed by others for others for goodness sakes). Not one of my favourites by Allen, but still pretty interesting and entertaining. It should be noted that Streep and Hemingways' performances exceed everyone else's by a mile.
